Tentacles, he says! The Tentacles from Planet xX! (looks to Bud) It's a lie, you know. These people just lie each other up. ~
Of course it's a lie. It's lunacy. (hollers) :
Nothing...just silence. People looking nervously around.

You honestly think he’s hiding? Having a laugh at your expense? Is that what you truly think, Bud? ANGLE TO Amanda and Sally, Irene and Hattie. Sally's got arms protectively around Billy. Everybody waiting, listen
(getting scared)
Go ahead. Search the store. You won't find him.
{hesitates)
Little Normy's gone. Death took your little Normy. All eyes turn. Here she comes in her canary-yellow pantsu

You listen but don't hear. You hear but don't believe. Who wants to go outside and see for himself? {looks to David) And what do you propose to do about it, Mr. David Drayton? What do you think you can do about it?

Can't somebody make her shut up? ‘MRS... CARMODY Are you scared, dearie? No, not yet, but you will be. The End Time has come. The moving finger has writ, not in flames, but in mist. The earth has spewed up Hell's abominations, and when you see them face to face, oh then you'll be scared, yes, scared aplenty when they drag you off! You'll be with little Normy soon enough!
(takes her elbow) That's enough now, Mrs. Carmody . That's just fine.
Don't you touch me! It's the end of everything! It's death!
It's a pile of shit.
Look, mister, don't you think we know how this sounds? But it's the flat-out truth. We all saw it.
(to Bud) Don't take our word. Come look.
Lead the way, Mr. Drayton. Let’s get this foolishness over with. David turns, glances to Jim and Myron. They don't want to but they nod in agreement anyway. They all enter:  50.

The men enter, flashlight beams sweeping the shadows, fac Pale and ghastly. Bud's bravado is draining away...once y get a person in the dark, logic flees. He can see the pla is trashed: boxes knocked over, toilet paper rolls everyw David brings him toward the loading door. Bud's flashligh beam finds the blood on the floor, a lot of it, long stre already turning brown, leading to the big roll-up door... »+-and there, curled on the ground, is that bit of tentac looking rubbery.

{a whisper) What the hell? David grabs the mop handle, pokes the tentacle...once, tw It moves, making Bud jump, the fragment clenching and unclenching convulsively, its barbed mouth gaping open as sScreaming...then it curls up and goes still again. Now t it's finally dead, it decays before their eyes at a start xate. Bud makes a choking sound of shock and disgust...
+-and they exit. Bud pauses, faces everybody in the store
People. It appears we may have a Problem of some magnitude here.

text: A DRIFTING SHOT takes us ominously through the Mist, past vague shapes of parked vehicles...and the market looms fr the murk, materializing before our eyes as CAMERA MOVES t the windows to reveal: : People inside. Piling big 50-pound bags of fertilizer and food like sandbags along the plate glass...

CAMERA HERE IS HANDHELD, DRIFTING AND PROBING, always res always on the move: WE PULL BACK from DAN MILLER, a middle-aged man on a ladd taping the cracks in the glass with packing tape while Jo AND BUDDY EAGLETON (brothers) hold the ladder.  Db. ANGLE DRIFTS BACK through a lot of activity -- bag after being laid down, more arriving from the back of the store while other items are also gathered and laid out: Mop handles. Cans of charcoal fluid. Knives. All imprompt defensive items. ANGLE FINDS Billy -- the boy's in plain of his father, being watched by Sally. Nearby, Norton is his "group," about ten people who have gravitated to his

You people are getting stampeded, don't you see? You have four witnesses to this supposed event. One of them I don't trust at all because he has a grudge against me. Of the remainder, two are hopelessly inebriated... He indicates Jim and Myron, who (yes) are pretty shitface now and still sucking down the beers.
What about the fourth? I guess that would make me a flat-out liar.
Yes, it would. I find that far easier to believe than tentacles.

Tell you what, Mr. Norton. Why don't you go out that door and around back? There's a big pile of return bottles Norm and I put out there this morning. You bring back one of those bottles...even one...I'11 take off my shirt and eat it.
I refuse to be sucked in by your pathetic delusions. The evidence here is flimsy bordering on ludi--
(cuts him off) This isn't a courtroom. You're not arguing a case. And you're not doing anything but damage talking the way you are.
And you can throw as much cow's blood around the loading dock as you want, you're still not fooling anybody...  $2.
Leave it alone, David. You can't convince some people there's a fire even if their hair is burning. Denial is a powerful thing.
This is absolutely moronic. Norton withdraws in disgust toward the back of the store.

Anybody who wants to discuss this rationally to find a means of rescue are welcome to join me. Those who want to take part in his travesty, go right ahead. I'11 have no part of it, nor would any thinking person. ANGLE SHIFTS (remember, CAMERA is drifting, restless, on move) to Mrs. Carmody eyeing them, sucking on a Tootsie P

Keep thinking, Mr. Lawyer. There is no defense against the will of God. No court of appeals in Hell. (to David) No defense here, neither. Not with all the bags of fertilizer in the world, not even if you stack 'em high as that prideful tower in Babel. They all just bags of shit now, ain't they?
I guess you'd be the expert on that. Dan enters frame, Joe following through with the ladder.

Got those windows taped up. Perhaps it'll do some good. David and Ollie trade a look -- they can’t believe that, don't want to be discouraging either. Amanda is the only who catches it. She draws closer:
That bad? David just give her a subtle nod -- yeah, that bad.
I have seen the signs. I have read the Revelations. There are those here I have told, but ain't none so blind as those who will not see.  53. She moves to the windows, pointing out at the Mist.
"And the temple was filled with the smoke from the glory of God, and from his power; and no man was able to enter the temple till the plaques of the seven angels were fulfilled."
Well, what are you saying? What are you proposing?
Proposing? Why, I am proposing that you prepare to meet your maker, Michael Hatlen!
Prepare to meet shit! Woman, your tongue must be hung in the middle so it can run on both ends! Myron's advancing on her, but Jim restrains him. ¢
Come on, pal, easy now... People are pausing now, drawn to the confrontation, as:

Doubters will doubt to the end! Yet a monstrosity did drag that poor boy away! Things in the mist! Every abomination out of a bad dream! Eyeless freaks! Pallid horrors! Do you doubt? Then go out! Go on out and say howdy-do!
A LITTLE GIRL bursts into tears, buries her face against FATHER'S leg. The adults are either disgusted or fascinat but all are silent and listening now.
Shut up, lady, God's sakes. David glances over, sees Billy peering with wide eyes.
You'll have to stop now, Mrs. Carmody. You're scaring the children. My little boy.
The children should be scared. Oh yes they should. Their heads been (MORE)

filled with lies, all this talk of modern God. Only one true God, the God of the Israelites. He’s a stern and vengeful God, and we been mocking Him far too long. Now he’s calling us to pay our debt in blood.
Blood?

That's right missy thing, blood. Like what trickles down your leg once a month. Why you think God gave women the curse? As a reminder. But that's just been a downpayment. Now we pay the rest. (looks around) Read the Good Book! It calls for blood! Expiation! Sacrifice! Amanda steps up calmly and slaps her hard across the face
You shut up that bad talk. Mrs. Carmody touches a hand to her mouth, finds a little there. It makes her smile...and she holds it up for all t see. Amanda backs away, realizing just how crazy she is.
Sorry, folks. This lady's perspective on things is a little too Old Testament for my Lutheran tastes.
She had it coming! I'd have done it myself! Carmody singles Sally out, drifting ominously toward her.
They'll get hold of you. Not today. Maybe tonight. When darkness comes. Sally shies back. Carmody turns slowly, addressing them a now, eyes going from face to face.
They'll come at night, and take someone else. See if they don't. And when they do, when you're next, then you'll come weeping to me. You'll beg Mother Carmody to show you what to do.  DD.
That's fine, but until then, if you don't shut up, we'll wrap some of this tape around your mouth.

You try it, Ollie Weeks. (turns to Amanda) And you, bitch. Hit me again if you dare. You'll be on your knees to me before it's through. She plants her Tootsie Pop back in her mouth, drifts quie off. People get out of her way. ANGLE FINDS one terrified WOMAN, pale and watching...already believing.
as the moment ends, everybody around him freaked-out and silent as they drift off to resume their preparations.
Those of you who aren't locals should know that Mrs. Carmody is well known in town for being unstable.
No shit. What was your first clue?
Okay, we can use the charcoal fluid and mops to make torches. And we got knives and such, God knows.
Which God, hers? He likes knives, apparently...
This may be a silly question, Bud, but you don't happen to have a gun . in the store?
Please. This isn't Dodge city. or Los Angeles. An old man, AMBROSE CORNELL, pipes up:
Got a shotgun in my truck. I could try for it, if you want.
I don't think that's a good idea, Mr. Cornell.  56.
I don’t either, son, but I thought I'd offer.
Well, I didn't think so...
Hold on a minute. All eyes turn to her. She looks very self-conscious as sh opens her purse, digs around, and pulls out a small Smith Wesson J-frame revolver. i
This gun...my husband's idea. : (embarrassed) i He insisted. He's away on business | a lot. It's not even loaded. :
So what good is it? She goes into her purse again, brings out two plastic spe loaders, each containing six rounds.
You know how to use it?
I shot it only once, on a target range. Dan takes the gun, manages to fumble the cylinder open.
Okay, we got a gun. Who knows how to shoot it? Well, I mean. People glance around at each other. Then, reluctantly:
I do.
You? You'll be too damn drunk to see before dark.

(ignoring him) I've done a lot of target shooting. I was state champion back in '94, David gives Ollie a look -- the little assistant manager full of surprises. Ollie takes the gun, loading and handl it with deft expertise. He cracks the cylinder, applies t speed-loader, shuts the cylinder with a flick of his wris  57.

Okay. You're in charge of the gun. (to Amanda) If that's okay? Amanda nods, relieved. Mike and Dan move off to help the piling the bags, while: David goes to Billy and Irene. The boy's eating a Hershey bar. David kneels, puts his hand on Billy's forehead.
Feeling better, champ?

(nods solemnly) How come nobody. comes and rescues us? Why don't those Army men call their friends to come get us? David glances over, sees Bisby, Jessup, and Donaldson apa from everybody else, having some kind of quiet but heated debate -- in fact, they seem on the verge of an argument. David finds it odd, but doesn't give it that much thought
I don't know.
You think Mommy's okay?
Billy, I just don't know. I wish I did, but I don't.
(eyes brimming tears) I want her awful bad. I'm sorry about the times I was bad to her. David hugs him, pulls him close.

Mommy loves you, Billy. And I bet she's fine. I promise you I'm going to do everything I can to get us back to her, okay? That's all you have to think about. Billy nods, miserable. David feels helpless, wanting to believe it himself. He looks up at Sally's trembling, tears running down her face desperately Sally and Irene.
Sally? Your folks still in Boston?  58.
Yeah. Till next week. So I guess they're okay.
I'm sure they are. You just be strong for them, dear. Suddenly, RAISED VOICES are heard coming this way:
You're crazy if you go out there!
Let us pass! Let us pass, please! David rises. Norton and his group (now on ly five people) appear with Joe dogging them, Mike joining in:
Wait, please, let's talk this thing through...
We have, and we've made our decision. ‘ We're leaving.
Whoa, now, hang on! Mike's right, we can talk it over, can’t we? Mr. Mackey's gonna barbecue some chicken on the gas grill, we can all sit down and eat and just--
And let you go on talking? I've been in too many courtrooms to fall for that. You've psyched out half a dozen of my people already.
"Your" people? What kind of talk is that? They're people, that's ali. You want to get ‘em killed? There are, for want of a better word, things out there in the mist--

Things, you say. We've been here since this morning, and I have yet to see a "thing." Nor has anybody else, and people have been staring out at that mist for hours. (looking around) Who has yet to see one?  59.
Back in the loading dock, jackass, dig the wax out of your ears!

No, no, no! That ground has been covered and covered! (turns) Listen, everybody! We have experienced some sort of natural or manmade disaster! That's all! The only way we can help ourselves is to seek rescue! We're going out!
No! You can't! One of Norton's group, an ELDERLY WOMAN, faces them:
Will you restrain us? Will you? The challenge is clear.. -use force or let them go. Softl
No. No, ma'am, I don’t think anyone will restrain you. Brent, listen...
I'm not discussing this further. Certainly not with you.
I know. I'm just asking a favor. Off Norton's questioning look, David grabs a package of w clothesline from all the supplies that have been gathered
Will you tie this around your waist?
What in God's name for?
It'll tell us you got at least three hundred feet. Something flickers in Norton's eyes -- a hesitation, like Norm had before he opened the loading dock door. But then
No. I will not.
I'll do it.  60. All eyes turn.
You throwing in with him?

Me? No thanks. I think your man there's a little too tightly wound. Gonna get somebody killed. (to Ambrose) I'm thinking we could use that shotgun of yours. I saw where you parked when I pulled in. Red pickup, right? Far entrance. Ambrose weighs this, digs his keys out, offers them.

You got brass balis, son. Shells are in the glove compartment. You can drive back. Pump the pedal three times to get ‘er started. The biker takes the keys, ties the clothesline to his bel (which has a huge "Live Free Or Die” buckle). Norton's bristling, but has no choice.
You want a knife? The biker lifts his shirt, reveals a buck knife in a scab
Got one. You just see to paying out that line. If it binds up, I'11 cut ‘er loose. Just so you understand. Davia nods. He turns to Norton, holds out his hand.
Brent. Good luck, man. Brent just stares at David's hand like it's a foreign obj

We'll send back help. Norton goes to the door, pushes it open, steps out. The others in his group file out aft er him...except one MAN, who freezes. Norton glances back at him. The guy just shakes his head, backs away in fear. Norton dismisses him in disgust. The biker pauses at the door, looks back at Mrs. Carmody.  61.
Hey, crazy lady. I believe in Goa, too. I just don't think he's the bloodthirsty asshole you make Him out to be.
Take it up with the Devil when you Grop in on him. Chew it over at your leisure. She gives him a chilly smile. He just turns, exits.

They'll die out there. Mark me. Norton's group starts off. People crowd to the windows, p over the "sandbags," watching. David and Ollie pay out th clothesline, keeping it from tangling. The group gets indistinct very quickly...then vanishes fr sight, swallowed by the Mist Silence now. Tension thick. People straining to see or he anything. The only sound is the clothesline quietly reeli out, rubbing softly against the door jamb. The seconds tick by. The line keeps being drawn out, foot after foot, yard after yard It suddenly stops, goes slack in David's hands. Pause. It starts again. Everybody remembers to breathe. The rope keeps going, at least two hundred feet of it now gone, cl in on three quarters. People are starting to get hopeful.

{a whisper) They're doing good. Real good. -+-and suddenly the line is yanked taut. Davia screams as rope-burns through his hands, whipsaws erazily from side side in the door, goes still, starts whizzing out again. is holding on, getting dragged, Ollie grabbing him and tr to hold him back... FAINT, DISTORTED SOUNDS come wavering out of the Mist, we and surreal: distant hellish screams, somebody yelling, a snatches of words...

--off me--oh Lord--off-- And now come other sounds, weirder by far: a long, Ww unearthly HOWL gives way to deep snufflings and savage, tearing GRUNTS...  oz. David yells, feet dug in, others jumping in to help, keep him from being pulled out the door... And the line abruptly goes slack out there. They fall bac a tangled heap. A final distant HOWL dies away to nothing David scrambles, pulling the line in as fast as he can, t to find the end of it. It piles up at his feet, the rope turning red as it's reeled in, soaked with blood, and: Here come the biker's legs getting dragged across the pav Tike a huge piece of bloody bait, the rope still looped t his belt...but that's all that's left of him. Everything the waist is bitten off, gone.
(near tears) Oh, God, close the door! Myron slams the door, face white, scared sober. Nobody sp in the long, shocked silence that follows, except:
(placid, quiet) Now do you see? Now do you believe?

TRACKING SHOT brings us along the sentries stationed at t barricaded plate glass, eight men peering out. Night is coming, deepening the shad wrapping the store in a shroud. The sodium vapor lamps in ‘parking lot look like eerie, distant planets in the gloo Ollie's at the end of the sentry line, peering out, gnawi chicken leg. Suddenly, a shadow seems to glide past out t He pauses, blinks, rubs his eyes. He glances over, sees D staring at him, gives him a strained smile.
You stare at something long enough, your eyes play tricks on you.
(softly) I saw it too.  DO. O£f Ollie's look, we go to:

"Lounge" is overstating things -- it's little more than a coffee room with a few lockers, a table and chairs, vendi machines, faded safety posters on the walls. CAMERA DRIFTS ominously, finding Sally. She's at her lock uniform hung up, gym bag at her feet, just pulling on her jeans. She seems very vulnerable in here ail alone. She gets her sneakers on, grabs her gym bag, heads for th exit, comes around the lockers -- Somebody's there. She stifles a scream, drops her bag. It's Jessup, the young soldier she was smiling at earlier the checkstands when he first came in.
Wayne. Jesus. You scared the shit out of me.
Sally--I'm sorry. Really. My bad. (hesitates) I...I saw you come in here. 1 thought. ..thought I'd come in and say hi. See how you're holding up.
Barely. How about you?
Worried about my folks, I guess. You know they live up on Shoreham Road...less than five miles from here. This mist...who knows how far “it's spread... (pause) What about yours?
They're out of town right now.
That's lucky. Means they're okay. Sally nods, trying to keep it together.
How soon you shipping out?
Couple of weeks.  64.
You scared about going over there?
Yeah. Sure I am. Their eyes meet. Pause. We feel the weight of things betw them that have been left unsaid for a long time.
Wayne? How come you never asked me out? We flirted all through high school. I know you like me. So how come you never asked me out?
Dunno. I always wanted to. Stupid, I guess. She kisses him. It turns passionate. They start getting c away...but she stops, pushes him away...
(backs off) ++-shit, I’m sorry...
+--mo, don't be, it's just... (beat) Shit. I don’t want it to happen Tike this. Not in a shitty locker room at work. It's not exactly the way I always imagined it, y'know?
(nods, beat) Let’s just stay in here a while, then...okay? Just the two of us? She lays her head on his shoulder...

--.and we find David's group sitting in an aisle: Billy, Amanda, Irene, Hattie. They're having a desultory meal of grilled chicken. Hattie's got Billy, clinging to him. Dav can't help noticing she's tense, verging on hysterical. H tries a tactic to get Billy out of earshot for a moment:
Hey, you gotta eat, big guy. Keep your strength up.
I'm not hungry.  65.
Well, maybe you'd bring me some more, huh? Go back there and get me some from Mr. Mackey, okay?
I'll go with you, Billy. Would that be okay?
"kay. David gives Amanda a grateful look. She rises, takes Bill hand, heads toward the back. David looks to Hattie.
You gonna keep it together?
How bad will it be tonight?
Hattie, I just don't know.

You let me keep Billy as much as you can. Okay? David, I'm...I think I'm in mortal terror. Yes, I believe that's what it is. But if I have Billy, I think I can be all right. I can be all right for him.
We're all terrified, dear. There's no shame in it.
I'm so worried about my Alan. The iast I saw him, he was out back mowing the yard. He's dead, I think. In my heart, I'm sure he's dead,
You don't know any such thing.
What about Steff, David? Don't you have some feeling about...about whether she’s all right?

It's killing me not knowing. That's why I'm gonna keep it together and not give up hope. So I can get us back to her, me and my boy. That's all that matters.  66. Suddenly, Ollie's there, beer in hand, crouching down:
There are things moving around out there.
What do you mean?

Shadows. Things in the mist. (off David's look) i'm not drunk. I've been trying, believe me. Wish I could. 1 thought my eyes were playing tricks, but Dan saw it too. So did Arnie Simms. Ollie tosses a careful look over his shoulder at Mrs. Car She's. sitting by herself, eating chicken Yavenously with hands, surrounded by bones like some cannibal queen.

That woman is nuts, but she may be right about one thing...I think those things out there get more active when it gets dark. (checks his watch) Daylight's just about gone. David looks up, sees Billy and Amanda returning up the ai Billy carefully carrying a plate of chicken. David smiles sees the boy munching a leg.

GORDON ENNIS is manning his post, eyes glazed from boredo and exhaustion. He clicks on one of the Coleman lanterns he can see, takes his eyes off the Mist long enough to sn piece of chicken, turns his eyes back to the window... +--and a flying thing comes right out of the Mist and SLA to the plate glass with a LOUD THUMP, attracted to the li clinging there before his eyes. Gordon jerks back... DAVID'’S GROUP +:-and Amanda freezes as Gordon's SCREAM erupts from the of the store. Billy drops the Plate, food all over the fl and his sneakers. David and Ollie jump to their feet --

Hattie! Watch Billy! ~~ and they burst from the aisle to see Gordon staggering away from the barricade in terror, fleeing toward the bac Sally and Wayne Jessup come running from the employee lou see David and the others racing toward:  67.

People come crowding. And what they see clinging to the g blows their minds with shock and disgust: a s ented BUG about two feet long, eight legs holding the glass with su pads, asymmetrical clusters of eyes revolving on individu stalks, clear membranous wings flexing wetly, a barbed st where the sexual organ might be.

Oh, God... As they watch, more of the bugs come flitting out of the thump-thump-thumping to the glass, clinging there...a swa of them, varying in size from one to two feet, milling . aimlessly, crawling over one other, dumb as houseflies. Mrs. Carmody comes strolling with a chicken leg in hand, licking grease from her fingers, eyes gleaming.

"And there came out of the smoke locusts upon the earth, and unto them was given power, as the scorpions of the earth have power." (a whisper) Wow. Look at those stingers. Ollie reaches up, gently taps the glass. A bug takes off, then lands again. Other people start tapping the glass; m the swarm flit off, but they always come back, settling.
(realizing) The light. I think they're attracted to the light.
Maybe we should douse the--HOLY SHIT!

iis words are lost as a bigger and more awful thing appea We'll call it a "bird" -- it's like a pelican in size, bu miniature pterodactyl designed by Hiernyomus Bosch in loo a sharp triangular head with diseased orbs for eyes, a be snout snaggly with teeth, flapping leathery wings. lies convulsing on the floor, the sting from the bug swel her neck up to twice its size, face and neck going black blue, dying horribly before our eyes, Jessup kneeling in helpless white-hot panic, grabbing her flailing hand...
